title: 112_hr6530
content: The Act may be cited as the "Global Free Internet Act of 2012". The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 emphasizes the importance of a single, open, global Internet for the free flow of information and products. It supports policies that encourage technology standards, respect user privacy, promote innovation, and allow for the free flow of information and trade in Internet-related goods and services. Certain governments and international bodies are also recognized in this context. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies contrary to a free, open Internet, including mandating unique technology standards, sponsoring unauthorized access to networks, and restricting Internet communications. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies that threaten the interests of the United States by sponsoring unauthorized access to networks, restricting Internet communications, monitoring Internet use, and imposing market access requirements that discriminate against other countries. These actions facilitate foreign governments' attempts to restrict the free flow of information on the Internet and promote "national Internets" in conflict. Certain actions from other countries threaten the interests of the United States by facilitating attempts to restrict the free flow of information on the Internet, promoting "national Internets," harming US workers and businesses, and risking the utility of the Internet for open communication and commerce. The Task Force on the Global Internet is established to address threats to the free flow of information and open communication on the Internet. The Task Force on the Global Internet, hosted by the Department of Commerce, consists of four individuals with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties, nominated by the public and appointed by the President. The Chairperson is selected from among the Task Force members, and the leader of the majority party in the Senate is also part of the Task Force. The Task Force on the Global Internet, hosted by the Department of Commerce, consists of individuals appointed by the President, with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties. Members serve renewable terms not exceeding 3 years, appointed by various government officials. The Task Force on the Global Internet, under the Department of Commerce, comprises experts in Internet policy and civil liberties appointed by the President for renewable terms up to 3 years. Various government officials, including the United States Trade Representative and the heads of relevant federal agencies, may provide personnel or services to assist the Task Force. The Task Force is responsible for developing and implementing strategies in response to foreign threats. The Task Force on the Global Internet, part of the Department of Commerce, is tasked with developing strategies to address foreign and domestic government policies that restrict international trade in Internet-related goods and services, impede the free flow of information, or threaten the open nature of the Internet. Additionally, the Task Force consults with civil society groups on Internet policy and civil liberties. The Task Force on the Global Internet, under the Department of Commerce, aims to address policies that hinder international Internet trade, restrict information flow, or jeopardize the open nature of the Internet. It consults with civil society groups, coordinates federal agencies, prepares reports, holds public hearings, and appoints a civilian Task Force member to lead and manage inquiries. The Task Force on the Global Internet, under the Department of Commerce, addresses policies hindering international Internet trade, information flow, and the open nature of the Internet. It consults with civil society groups, coordinates federal agencies, prepares reports, holds public hearings, and appoints a civilian Task Force member to lead inquiries. SEC. 4. REPORT AND ACTION PLAN TO THE PRESIDENT AND CONGRESS. The Task Force must provide an annual report and action plan to the President and Congress, identifying acts, policies, or practices that hinder fair market access or impose unjustifiable restrictions on Internet-related goods and services. This includes promoting technology standards that deviate from international norms or lead to discriminatory practices. The Task Force annual report must identify measures that hinder fair market access or impose unjustifiable restrictions on Internet-related goods and services. This includes promoting technology standards that diverge from international norms or threaten the interests of the United States in global Internet communications. The report must estimate the impact on US commerce and Internet users, designate priority concerns, outline a response strategy for Federal departments, and provide information on actions taken. The Task Force annual report identifies priority concerns, outlines a response strategy for Federal departments, and provides information on actions taken in response to measures hindering fair market access or imposing unjustifiable restrictions on Internet-related goods and services. Public participation is sought through notices, public hearings, and a dedicated website. Classified annexes may be included if deemed appropriate. The Task Force seeks public participation through notices, public hearings, and a dedicated website. It consults with relevant government agencies, shares information with civil society groups, and considers input from various sources, including reports submitted under the Trade Act of 1974. The Task Force, in consultation with relevant agencies and civil society groups, considers information from various sources, including reports submitted under the Trade Act of 1974. The report and action plan are published in the Federal Register, omitting certain information transmitted to Congress. SEC. 5 requires the United States Trade Representative to investigate and take actions against foreign governments or international bodies for priority concerns identified in annual reports. SEC. 6 involves review and investigation by the Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice. SEC. 6 requires the Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General to review and investigate acts, policies, or practices that may violate antitrust laws. The term "antitrust laws" includes the Clayton Act and section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Task Force must submit a report to Congress and the President within 2 years of the enactment of this Act, assessing existing trade agreements' effectiveness in promoting international trade in Internet-related goods and services, technology standards, Internet security, information flow, and user interests. It also recommends modifications or new agreements to advance these objectives. Congress believes future trade agreements should include these goals. The Task Force recommends modifications or new agreements to advance objectives in promoting international trade in Internet-related goods and services, technology standards, Internet security, information flow, and user interests. Congress believes future trade agreements should include these goals and the report may contain a classified annex if deemed appropriate. Public participation is sought through notices, public hearings, and a dedicated website for timely information. The Task Force is required to consult with relevant federal departments, civil society groups, and consider information from various sources. They must also publish their report and action plan in the Federal Register. The Task Force, in consultation with federal departments and civil society groups, must publish a report and action plan in the Federal Register, excluding certain information transmitted to Congress. The Task Force will coordinate with various entities for standards-related training and establish a process for receiving input from businesses and experts.
